markdownRemark.html:
I havenâ€™t written anything in like 8 years but thatâ€™s because right as I was trying to wrap up my Maxwellâ€™s equations series in May, I interviewed for a CTO position and got it! ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰ðŸŽ‰

The company I now work at is called Iris Works and itâ€™s a startup affiliated with DeveloperTown Starts. Right now thereâ€™s 5 employees, including me, so itâ€™s small as hell. And of course that also means Iâ€™m wearing 10 different hats: software engineer, devops engineer, product manager, project manager, designer, etc.

Itâ€™s a lot to handle, especially since Iâ€™ve never done it before. But the good thing is that Iâ€™ve learned more since in the last 4 months than any previous job because Iâ€™ve literally have had to figure it all out through trial and error and itâ€™s allowed me to grow fast. Itâ€™s also an extreme mindset shift from being an individual contributor at Lessonly, especially now that I am a manager.

I was (and am still) so used to picking up a story, writing code that meets the acceptance criteria, getting it QAed and merged into master, then doing it all over again. I mean, I still do that, but even with all the other roles I have to play, it was still just me being an individual contributor. However, in August we hired a junior software engineer who is my first ever direct report. I think out of everything, learning how to be an effective manager is the hardest thing Iâ€™ve ever had to do.

Iâ€™m gonna be honest and admit that Iâ€™m pretty terrible at it right now, but Iâ€™m reading books and articles and talking with my awesome CEO about effective management to get better at it. So hereâ€™s hoping in three months I can say that September was the worst management month Iâ€™ll have.

Also, going forward I want to try to document things that Iâ€™ve learned (I have a massive backlog of posts already) and things Iâ€™m struggling with. Iâ€™ll try not to abandon my blog for another four months again.

frontmatter.description: I haven't written anything in like 8 years but that's because right as I was trying to wrap up my Maxwell's equations series in May, I interviewed for a CTO position and got it!
